Christian Democratic leaders in parliament tactlessly made it clear that
Pella was not their man* that they would have preferred someone else.
It was only the strenuous intervention of De Gasperi that got the party
fairly well in line for Pella last autumn. But the political honeymoon be¬
tween Pella and the country lasted much longer than that between the premier
and his party.
De Gasperi and other Christian Democratic leaders were deeply disturbed
by Pella1s handling of the explosive Trieste question. Some thought he was
trying to use that emotional issue to turn his supposedly stopgap government
into a durable one and establish himself firmly in the premiership. It was
said that Pella was spending too much time on foreign affairs and neglecting
pressing domestic questions. Some Christian Democrats thought Pella should
turn over the foreign ministry to someone else, for he was serving simultane¬
ously as premier, foreign minister and budget minister.
Christian Democratic trade unionists, led by Giulio Pastors, criticised
Pella for the firm stand taken by the government in the wave of industrial
strikes that struck Italy in December. Their union, the CISL, had gone along
with the Communist-dominated CGIL In backing those strikes.
And It riled many Christian Democrats that Pella had to depend on Mon¬
archist support for a sure parliamentary majority and they were constantly
asking what price the premier was paying for that support.
Bo much, then, for the party's side of the case* There is also Pella's
side, and It too, deserves serious consideration. First of all, even some
Christian Democrats vigorously opposed to Aldisio believed Pella had a valid
point when he defended the freedom of the premier to choose his own cabinet
ministers. It's the same argument often advanced in America that a President
should have a cabinet of his own choosing — forgetting for a moment the very
basic difference between the American system of checks and balances and the
European parliamentary system.
Secondly, Pella toofc up the burden of forming a government when that Job
was truly a thankless task. Be took on that Job at a critical time for the
Italian democracy. And the fact that he succeeded where De Gasperi mid
Plccionl had failed brought an end to the long summer crisis.
Pella did that Job well enough to restore the faith of Italians in their
eight-year-old democratic system and to win genuine widespread support for
himself in the country.
Pella can make out a case for the argument that his own party has never
appreciated the Job he did and that it never gave him the support he deserved
during his four and a half months as premier* rtParty man*1 or not, he was do¬
ing a Job for the party as well as for the country. And he had served both
party and country faithfully and well as budget and treasury minister for manj
years.
So far as the Trieste issue is concerned, Pella can argue with some evi¬
dence that it was forced on him and that De Gasperi himself had started the
ball rolling by a much tougher stand on that issue after the elections last
June.
